results.title: Australia calling
results.brief_description: A panorama of Australia, moving from Western Australia through South Australia, Tasmania, Victoria, the A.C.T., N.S.W. and Queensland. Scenes include timber getting, gold mining, grape and apple harvests, dairying, skiing, Federal Parliament, Sydney attractions, Blue Mountains, caves and beaches, cane cutting and the Great Barrier Reef.

results.title: Australia builds
results.creator_credit: United Nations. Film Board and Dept of Public Information
results.brief_description: Australia is playing her part as a member of the United Nations family by giving a home and new life to many Europeans. But to continue to feed her growing population she has had to develop her resources to a greater extent; the Snowy Mountains project is one way in which she is doing this. Australia has also found it necessary to buy machinery and equipment from dollar countries. Dollars are in short supply, but as a member of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development, the Government has been able to negotiate a series of dollar loans.

results.title: Australia big beef country
results.brief_description: This film is concerned with local beef production in Australia’s tropics with the emphasis being placed on the use of improved pastures and new breeding stock to improve quality. Hygienic conditions for the production of boneless beef is ensured through government inspection. No other credits available.

results.title: Australia at work
results.creator_credit: Appleseed Productions, Focus Audio-Visual Services, Mervyn Dober and Greg Shepherd
results.brief_description: This series of four videos has been compiled from extensive footage of the working environment. Hundreds of Australians from all walks of life have been interviewed to paint a fascinating picture of the Australian working community.

results.title: Australia at War 1914-1918: an Account of the Australian Force in the Great War
results.creator_credit: Australian Commonwealth Film Unit, Australian War Memorial, Frank Bagnall and Barrie Pattison
results.brief_description: This detailed account of “the war to end all wars” comprises actual footage shot on the battlefields of Europe and the Middle East. Commencing with troops leaving Australia, it documents the major battles campaigns of Australian and New Zealand troops including those in Egypt, the Somme and Cambrai in which 60,000 Australians died. Shows rare footage from the only roll of film taken at Gallipoli and includes footage from the work of Hubert Wilkins and Frank Hurley acquired from the archives of the Australian War Memorial.

results.title: Australia at school
results.creator_credit: Australian National Film Board and Geoffrey Collings
results.brief_description: Shows a range of schools from small country towns through to high schools in Sydney, grades from kindergarten to last year of high school. “A film outlining Australia’s system of primary and secondary education”. Cinematography by Frank Bagnall.

results.title: Australia and the stars
results.creator_credit: ABC-TV (Australia), Monash University, Open Learning Agency of Australia and Michael Hollander
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Astronomy: an Open Learning unit”.
The Southern Hemisphere provides some of the best viewing for astronomers. Galaxies and Nebulae close to the Southern Cross constellation are more observable and provide useful data to astronomers studying the wonders of the universe. This program also provides a brief history of astronomy from a Southern Hemisphere perspective by highlighting Captain Cook’s voyage to Australia.

results.title: Australia 2001:Thomas Keneally leads the push for a republi
results.creator_credit: Australia. Special Broadcasting Service, John Walsh and Kevin Ryder
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Face the press”.
Paolo Totaro hosts a discussion between Thomas Keneally (Chairman of the Australian Republican Movement), David McNichol (The Bulletin) and D.D. McNichol (The Australian) on the issue of a Repblican Australia by the year 2001. They discuss the potential benefits to Australia becoming a republic, when this is likely to cccur, the politicalisation and composition of the Republican movement, possible candidates for Head of State and selection criteria, the Constitutional Commission 1988 and the liklihood of a hidden agenda within the Republican movement to undermine the current political system.
